resources.string: Are you sure you want to quit the app?

Are you sure you want to reset the app? 
Hereby all progress is lost. 

The app restarts within a few seconds.
Learn how to protect yourself against Internet \"Phishing\" dangers!
If you want to share your gameplay with your friends on google + and save your score online, sign in with Google+.
Please note, that it is currently not possible to delete the services and rankings. The score can be deleted.
Your online score has been deleted.

Your online score has been loaded.
Tests on the state of knowledge

Here are three links, with the help of which you can test your knowledge of phishing. 
These tests are better to perform on the tablet (because of the presentation of the examples). 

By clicking on the quiz links you will be redirected to the website of SoSciSurvey. SoSciSurvey was designed to conduct an online survey in a scientific context, allowing for the simultaneous evaluation and improvement of NoPhish.
Here you will find a collection with external links to the topic on Phishing. This does not claim to be complete.

This app was developed by the research group SECUSO developed by the TU Darmstadt. The first version of this app was developed by Clemens Bergmann and Gamze Canova as part of their master\'s thesis. This app was evaluated based on user studies and developed based on the results of the evaluations. The changes were made by Philipp Rack. English translation by Chris Wilder

Darmstadt University of Technology
Department of Computer Science
Specialization Security, Usability & Society
Management: Prof. Dr. Melanie Volkamer
building S4|14
Mornewegstr. 30
64293 Darmstadt

E-Mail: kontakt@secuso.org
Area of the topic of conversation
Interlocutor does not appear in the web address at all
Similar conversation partners in the department area
Similar conversation partners in the topic of conversation
Similar conversation partners in the who area
Typo / Spelling Errors in the Who area
Similar characters in the Who area.
The scope of the security level
Here you can enter any text, which should appear in the e-mail.
Please give as authentic as possible (or existing ones) E-Mail Address a, which should appear as the sender.
The sender or recipient e-mail is invalid. Please check your entries.
Now please check your emails via your smartphone. You should have received a fake e-mail. Read this thoroughly. About this you will come back to the app.
Please note, that the arrival of the email can take a few minutes. Possibly, you also have to check your junk / spam folder. If the e-mail does not arrive, please enter a different sender address.

Now it's your turn

1. Click on the button "Click here", to open a practice website.

2. Wait until the website is fully loaded.

3. Solve the task on the website. When you have completed the task, you will be automatically redirected to the app.

Phishing

"Phishing" is a neologism that is a combination of the two English terms representing "phreaking" (hack) and "fishing" (fishing). This is a technique fraudsters use to try to use fake messages, Distribute malicious software (such as viruses) or such as your sensitive data. Passwords, account information or credit card information, too "fishing".

To get the sensitive data, the scammers send you fake messages (such as emails, text messages, social networks or Skype). At first glance, these messages look like messages from people or institutions you trust (such as Amazon, Facebook, or your bank). The range of fraudulent messages ranges from messages requesting the disclosure of private data, from messages with dangerous file attachments to "classic Phishing" News, that is news with dangerous links. Using these classic phishing scams, the scammers want to get their potential victims to (premature) click on such dangerous links. If the recipient follows such a link, he either directly loads malware onto the device used (e.g., PC or Smartphone), or he is directed to a website of the fraudsters who pretend to be the website of the imitated institution. However, it is a fake copy, a so-called phishing site. If you enter your sensitive data here, they will be immediately picked up by the fraudsters.
Done!\n\nYou have the introduction 1 successfully completed.

string.name: level_00_intro_02_text_01
string.b: Send yourself an e-mail from any sender

resources.string: Not arrived at Google?\n\nYou probably thought you were getting to Google\'s website. Unfortunately, you can but the links in an e-mail or. In general, trust links as well as the given email sender and the rest of the email content.

General information:

1.) It is easy to fake the sender of an e-mail. Anyone can do this, even without much prior knowledge. Accordingly, you should be careful when evaluating the trustworthiness of news (Emails, Skype, Social Networks etc.). This is especially true if they contain a link. Not only for links that seem to be familiar to you, but also for those who, for example. �Click Here� mean, you should be careful.

2.) Furthermore, clicking on links does not necessarily lead to the web address specified in the link. Most e-mail applications do not provide a way to see the real goal of links at first glance. 

The real goal of a link is experienced by letting your finger on the link. Depending on the mail program, the destination is then displayed either in a small window directly next to the mouse pointer, or in the status bar at the bottom of the opened mail.

Phishing-Emails and phishing websites you can just based on the web address (of the link) recognize. Therefore, in this app, we'll explain how to verify the authenticity of web addresses before clicking.

By the way, that does not just apply to e-mails!\n\nDangers do not just lurk behind links in emails, but generally whenever you click on a link (e.g., on another website, in an SMS or in messages on Facebook or Twitter).

Anyone can create web addresses and website copies!\n\nAnyone can create web addresses and website copies. Displaying an identical copy of a web page there is almost effortless and involves almost no cost. That, if you land on a website, the displayed website may look correct at first glance, but is actually the copy of a familiar website, which was created to harm you.
Original\n\nIn the following we show you a part of the original Website of Facebook. At the web address https://m.facebook.com/ (outlined in green) you can tell that this website is the original.

Copy/Phishing website\n\nIn the following we show you a part of a copied Website of Facebook or \"Phishing-Website\", the under the fake web address https://pages.no-phish.de/ (outlined in red) is shown.

Detect a phishing website

It is important that you always check the web address before entering data on the website, especially if you receive an unexpected email with a link.

With this app you learn how to use the Check web addresses.

Further gameplay

,Because there are different types of attacks that can be detected when checking web addresses, we have divided the tasks into different levels. 

Each level consists of two parts:
Here you can move the web address right and left to view it completely.

Note: We would like to point out to you that we help you with this app, to protect you against a very common form of phishing. Unfortunately there are some other species as well. If you want to know more about this later, then click in the menu \"More information\".

Here we go!\n\nBefore you drop us off the chair from boredom, Let\'s do it a bit more interactive and start the game. In the first two levels necessary basic knowledge is taught. In the following levels you will learn, Detect phishing attacks based on web addresses.

The address bar

First, you need to know how to get to the web address with your smartphone. This is the same with every Android browser. Two things are important for this:

1.) Find the address bar.
2.) View the web address completely.

The Who section is the most important area for detecting phishing URLs. In the jargon he is called domain. Usually this is displayed in the status bar.

On mobile devices (Smartphones und Tablets) the procedure depends on identifying the web address that is behind a link, however, strongly from the device. Mostly you have to press the link for about 2 seconds, but you do not click it.

Below are the two most commonly used systems, Android and iOS.

Find the address bar

Many websites are so extensive, that the actual website is displayed on the entire display and therefore the address bar is not visible.

But you can pull down the finger on the website so long (if necessary several times), until you arrive at the top of the web page and the address bar appears.

View the web address completely

Unfortunately, once the address bar appears, you will not always see the full web address, as it is often too long. However, it is very important to look at them as a whole.

To view the entire web address, you have to tap the address text with your finger.
View the web address completely\n\nAs a result, the web address will be highlighted and you will see the end of the web address.
Now you have to drag the web address to the right with your finger (if necessary several times), until you reach the beginning of the web address.
By pulling left and right, you can look at the entire web address.
Done!\n\nYou have completed the Introduction 2 successfully.
Hints: In the following levels, you\'ll learn how to differentiate trusted web addresses from phishing web addresses (called phishs).

Structure of web addresses

To recognize a fake website based on web addresses, It is important to understand the structure of a web address. In this and the following levels you will learn this gradually.

First an example of a web address:

The important components of a web address\n\nWeb addresses are very complex. For this reason, we would like to explain everything as simplified as possible. For this we look at the website, that you visit, from now on as yours \"Interlocutor\". Already in the web address you will learn (as in a conversation) the first important information, which we will discuss in more detail later.
The important components of a web address\n\nThe following graphic summarizes what the individual parts of a web address say about the conversation.

The purple area represents the security level of the conversation. Possibilities for this are \"http://\" and \"https://\". What the difference is, you will experience in an advanced level. The area highlighted in blue gives you information about the person you are talking to and the orange area tells you the topic of conversation. This area may also be missing.

Focus - Information about the conversation partner himself\n\nIn this and the next few levels, we will mainly deal with the blue-backed part of the web address, because it is very important to know who your interlocutor is! \ n \ nThe area between \""http://\" and the third Slash \"/\" So gives you information about your conversation partner, talk about the website. You can now ignore the remaining areas.

Structure of the interlocutor area

This area is divided into individual blocks by dots.

Remember: These blocks are read from right to left.
Location information\n\nThe first block (from the right) tells you that \"Location\" your conversation partner. In this case \"de\" for Germany.
Information about the conversation partner\n\nThe second block (from the right) tells you which one \"Companies\"" your conversation partner belongs.
Details of departments\n\nFrom the third block (from the right), describe all remaining blocks (there may be several) different\"Departments\" of your conversation partner.

The Who area\n\nThe most important two blocks of a web address are the first two blocks (viewed from the right) in the area \"Information about conversation partners\". We call him \"Who area\" (Company + Location). This area must be from each interlocutor,(i.e. each website), to be registered at one central location. Already registered names can not be registered again. These two blocks tell you, who your conversation partner really is, so you should always identify and check them.
Examples\n\nBelow are a few examples of web addresses. First, think about which area in the given web addresses is the who-area. Then check your results by continuing.
Examples - Resolution\n\nBelow are a few examples of web addresses. First, think about which area in the given web addresses is the who-area. Then check your results by continuing.
If you are unsure as to who your conversational partner is, ask for help directly with him.

Now it's your turn:

After the previous examples, you should now determine yourself who the Who-range of the following web addresses.

Touch the appropriate place and click on "�berpr�fen", if your answer is to be checked.
Tap now the who area of the following web addresses.
Unfortunately, you could not identify the Who section. Therefore, you lose a life.
Very good! You were able to identify the who area.
Done!\n\nCongratulations! You have completed the level successfully. On to the next Level!

Attack by IP address as the who area

Phishers use various deceptions, to make web addresses trustworthy, although they are not.

You will gradually learn with which tricks they try, to fool you.

In this level, we'll cover one of the simplest tricks of using IP addresses instead of terms in the who's area of the web address.
IP-Addresses\n\nJust as our homes are addressed by street names, computers are identified on the Internet with so-called IP-Address.
An IP address is a sequence of 4 blocks of numbers separated by dots.

string.name: level_04_intro_03_text_02
string.b: Attack by known interlocutors in the department

resources.string:
Use of IP addresses may be legitimate, but you should remain suspisious of any web address containing only the IP address. Especially if the name of the conversation partner does not show at all

Another trick is not to use the conversation partner in the web address. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this Level. 

When checking whether the other party in the web address occurs the following is good to know::

In the wer area, only small letters and numbers can be used, as well as a hyphen ( - )
- Amazon becomes amazon.de
- VHS becomes vhs.de
- Deutsche Bank becomes deutsche-bank.de
-1&1 becomes 1und1.de

Web addresses do not necessarily begin with www (applies to real and Phishing URLs).

Web addresses could previously contain no mark ( � ) used over a vowel. Therefore ( � ) are often converted, (e.g., "�") in "ue" at www.muenchen.de.

Some phishers do not even bother, mention the name of your correspondent in the web address. If the web address does not contain the name of your correspondent, then Do not enter any data on this website, even if the who section sounds trustworthy! Note: During the quiz you may have to scroll from right to left to see the entire URL.\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address that applies this principle. In the second example, your conversation partner is secure-login.com (highlighted in blue). This is the main area of the web address, the who area. Do not enter any data on this website, even if the web address sounds trustworthy!

Attack by well-known interlocutors in the department area\n\nAnother trick is the use of known names in the area of departments of a web address. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this level.

In memory of

The area between "http://" and the third Slash "/" Gives you information about your conversation partner, (i.e. via the website).

This area is divided into blocks by dots and the blocks are read from right to left.

Designation of departments\n\nThe most important part of a web address, the who-section must also be registered by the phisher, and already-registered names can not be re-registered. The area of the departments (highlighted in light blue) of a web address, however, anyone can call as he wants.

Phishers can easily use known interlocutors in their departments, to deceive you. So do not rely on this area. Also always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the who-area. Does the section of the departments contain the well-known interlocutors and contains the Who section but nonsense, disinterested or even trustworthy interlocutors instead of the name of your interlocutor, then Do not enter any data on this website!\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address that applies this principle. In the example your partner is badcat.de and secure-update.com (blue). This is the main area of the web address, the who area. Your conversation partner is not google.com or microsoft.com! These two are just the names of a department of each company. This area is not relevant to your investigation of the web address. That\'s why we read web addresses from right to left:: the who area is more important than the department!

Attack by using known interlocutors in the topic of conversation\n\nAnother trick to fool you, is a well-known conversation partner, to use in the topic of conversation. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this level.

Area of the topic of conversation

Now we would like to deal with another area of the web address, the topic of conversation.

The area after the third Slash "/" tell you about what you talk to your conversation partner, So the website, speak.

The area of the topic of conversation is in the hands of the Phishers. That is, he can call this area as he likes. He can also incorporate known interlocutors or even entire web addresses. So just look at the most important two blocks of a web address, the Who section, to check who your conversation partner actually is. Do not trust the topic or the topic of conversation. Does the topic of conversation contain known contacts or web addresses, and does the ad area contain an IP address?, nonsensical, disinterested or even unworthy of conversation partner instead of the name of your interlocutor, then do not enter any data on this website!\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address, which applies this principle. In the example is your conversation partner 95.130.22.98 (IP-Address) bzw. account-settings.de (blue background). This is the most important area of the web address, the who area. Your conversation partner is not google.com or facebook.com (orange background). These are just part of the topic of conversation here. This area is not relevant to your investigation of the web address. Especially for such attacks it is very important to make sure that you have scrolled to the beginning of the web address where http(s):// appears for the first time.

Attack by similar interlocutors in the Who area\n\nAnother trick to fool you is the use of names in the who area, which are very similar to the name of the person you are familiar with. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this Level.

You have to remember how the Who section of the web addresses, you normally visit, looks like. Namely, the phisher can register names that are very similar to the one you are familiar with. Therefore always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the Who section. Contains the Who-Area only a similar modification of you previously familiar Who-Area, then Do not enter any data on this website!

Below are three examples of phishing web addresses, who apply this principle. In the examples, your conversation partner is each facebook-login.com, apple-support.com or. ebay-verify.com (blue background). These are each the Who-areas of the web addresses. The Who-areas are similar to the original, but they are fake!

Be careful English words Name and pronunciation:

appel.de instead of apple.de
googel.de instead of google.de

The most important area of a web address, the Who-Area, must also be registered by the phisher. The phisher can take a familiar Who section of a website, incorporate a typo or even a misspelling in the name and then register that name as its creator. So always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the Who section. So read this area letter by letter. Does the Who-Area contain a typo or a speller, then Do not enter any data on this website!\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address that applies this principle. In the first example is your conversation partner mircosoft.com, in the second twitetr.com (blue background). The Who section contains a letter wheel.

string.name: level_07_intro_04_text_03
string.b: Typo / Spelling Errors in the Who-Aarea

resources.string: 1.) If the Who-Area contains only a similar modification of the previously familiar Who-Area, then do not enter any data on this website!
2.) Contains the Who-Area a typo, then enter here no data!
3.) If the Who-Area contains a spelling error, then do not enter any data on this website!

Attack by typos / spelling errors in the Who-Area

Another trick to fool you, In the registration of the Who-Area you have to insert a typo / spelling error in the Who-Area. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this Level.

Example text for clarification:
Aoccdrnig to a rscheearch of the Cabrmidge Uvinersity it deosn't mttaer, in waht oredr the ltteers in a wrod are, the olny iprmoetnt tihng is taht the frist and lsat ltteer be at the rghit pclae. The rest can be mses and you can sitll raed it wouthit porbelm. That is, bcuseae the huamn mnid deos not raed ervey lteter by istlef, but the wrod as a wlohe.

The most important part of a web address, the who-area must also be registered by the phisher. The phisher can simply insert a misspelling in familiar areas and then register that name with the misspelling. So always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the Who-Area, exactly on, because letter turners are difficult to recognize. Contains the Who-Area a letter turn, then Do not enter any data on this website!\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address, which applies this principle. In the example is your conversation partner twitetr.com (blue background). The Who section contains a letter wheel.

Attack by dispassionate or nonsensical names in the Who area\n\nAnother trick is the use of non-referenced or even senseless names in the Who-Area of a web address. We are dealing with this kind of attack at this level.

The most important area of a web address, the Who-Area, must also be registered by the phisher. So always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the Who-Area, contains the Who section name. If it make\'s no sense or nothing with the service or, the business of your correspondent, then Do Not enter any data on this website!\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address that applies this principle. In the examples, your conversation partner is each hsezis.de or. badcat.com (blue background). This is the Who-Area of the web address. These obviously do not make sense!

Attack by trustworthy-sounding conversation partners in the Who area\n\nAnother trick to fool you, is the use of trustworthy-sounding interlocutors in the who-section of a web address. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this level.

The most important area of a web address, the Who Area, must also be registered by the phisher. So always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the Who section. If the Who-area contains names that sound trustworthy, but still have nothing to do with the name of your correspondent, then Do not enter any data on this website!\n\nBelow is an example of a phishing web address that applies this principle. In the example is your conversation partner security-update.de (blue background). This is the main area of the web address, the who area. Do not enter any data here, even if the web address sounds trustworthy!

Attack by similar characters in the Who area\n\nAnother trick to fool you is replacing letters in the Who domain with other very similar looking characters or numbers. We are dealing with this kind of attack in this level.

The most important area of a web address, the Who Area, must also be registered by the phisher. The phisher can replace letters in your familiar name with other similar characters or numbers, so the who-section looks almost identical to your familiar name. So always look at the most important two blocks of the web address, the Who section. If the who field contains replacements of letters by other similar characters or numbers, thenDo not enter any data on this website!\n\nExamples of phishing web addresses that use this principle:

Further examples:
m --> rn
h --> ln
k --> lx
d --> cl
ap --> qo
o --> 0 (Caution: only lowercase letters are used)

The security level of the conversation\n\nDiscussions with companies can have a low or high security level. The first section of a web address gives you information about the security level. In this level we are dealing with this area.

The scope of the security level\n\nDuring the game you encountered two different variants of the security level, whose meaning you have not yet met: https:// and http://. The first section of the web address represents the security level. We will with the explanation of https:// begin and then border on it from http:// .

https

Captures a web address https:// on, is a high-security conversation (if the browser does not warn you). The https:// assures you the following:

1.) Your conversation gets no other (encryption of communication).

2.) Your interlocutor can identify himself to a third trustworthy party (authentication of the interlocutor).

https - Encryption of communication

Captures a web address https:// on, it means that the conversation takes place in a closed space, away from the public. That nobody gets to know what you are talking about with the website gets me what you talk about with the website or which user input you submit (Username, password, account information, etc.). The communication is thus encrypted. Especially when entering passwords or other sensitive data, encryption is very important.

In the following example is your conversation partner deutsche-bank.de (blue background). It will https:// used (purple background), i.e. nobody can read what data you send to deutsche-bank.de.

https - Authentication of the conversation partner

The https:// also assures you that your interlocutor, who is indicated in the Who area, is really this one. In detail, the identity of your interlocutor was checked by a so-called certification body.

In the following example is your conversation partner deutsche-bank.de (blue background). The web address starts with https (purple background). Thus, a certification authority confirms the identity of you deutsche-bank.de.

http

Captures a web address http:// On, the conversation is a low security level. The http:// means the following:

1.) Everyone can hear your conversation, i.e. the communication becomes Not encoded

2.) Your correspondent did not identify himself to a third trustworthy party

For user input (user name, password, account data, etc.) you are in public, everyone can hear this. The communication is therefore not encrypted. In addition, you can not be sure that the specified in the Wer-area conversation partner is actually the one, for which he pretends. Therefore, you should not enter sensitive data on such websites, even if the Who-area is in order. Instead, you should contact the provider and point out this problem.

Only add https:// Data\n\nWIf you enter data on a website, you should always make sure that https:// is used so that no one can read your data and they do not fall into the wrong hands. So, if you checked the who section and additionally https:// is used, you can be sure that no one can read your input and that they do not fall into the wrong hands.

Danger! Never rely solely on the existence of https://, because even phishers can use https:// . So always look at the who\'s area to be sure, that you really communicate with exactly the person you wanted to communicate with.\n\nIn the following example your contact is phisher.de (blue background), and not facebook. The https:// confirms that your conversation partner really phisher.de is and that no one else can hear your conversation with him.Do not let go of it https:// to deceive, do not enter any data here!

Comment

Some websites do not use by default https://, when the user needs to enter data. Consequently, you should always pay particular attention when entering data, who is your conversation partner and whether https:// is used. If no https:// used, you can try that http:// the web address with https:// to replace and press Enter. More information about https:// you find in Level 10.

Please lean any in this level http:// Web addresses, even if the Who range is okay. Also pay attention to phishing websites that use https:// !
Congratulations!\n\nYou made it through all levels. Finally, we would like to give you some valuable hints.

Confusing but legitimate web addresses

In this game you have learned, as you can see from web addresses, if you are on a phishing website. To describe many relevant features in an understandable way, we introduced the analogy, to view the visited website as your conversation partner. The web address provides you with relevant information about the conversation.

Unfortunately, sometimes it happens that the web addresses of legitimate websites, look suspiciously like phishing web addresses.

On the following pages we would like to give you two examples.

Confusing but legitimate web addresses\n\nThe regular website of Commerzbank can be reached at the web address given below. The Who-Area in commerzbank.com (highlighted in blue). So far, the web address looks very trustworthy, which it is.

If the user now wants to conduct online banking, he will reach the web address given below. Here is the Who-Area at once commerzbanking.de (highlighted in blue). As you can see, the Who section is just a similar variation of the Who section of the regular Commerzbank website, i.e. you would identify this website as phishing. This is not a phishing web address.
Confusing but legitimate web addresses\n\nHere\'s another example of two legitimate web addresses, the second looks like a phishing web address, but it\'s not:

Help us to make the internet safer

Sometimes legitimate web addresses can look like phishing web addresses. That's why it's important, to know exactly, What are the areas of your visited websites!
In such confusing cases, we would like to suggest that you contact the appropriate company or bank. For example, you can find the contact details using Google's search engine. Never use the contact information provided on a potential Phishing-Website. Do not enter any data before you have made sure! First, this way you can be sure that you will not enter data on fake websites. Second, you can complain why the company or bank is using and contributing to such confusing web addresses, to make the internet a bit safer.

https://

You have learned that https:// a web address assures two things:

1.) Your conversation gets no other (encryption of communication).

2.) Your interlocutor can identify himself to a third trustworthy party (authentication of the interlocutor).

https:// - Authentication of the conversation partner\n\nThis means that a so-called trusted certification authority assures that the interlocutor is really who he claims to be. This certification authority will perform certain identity checks and post on a successful review of the Who-Area a so-called certificate. This certificate assures you that the person you are talking to is really the person listed in the who\'s area.

https:// - Identity Tests\n\nUnfortunately, the great competition and the price pressure among the certification bodies leads in part to superficial and simplified awarding of certificates. It is possible for certificates to confirm identities that they should not confirm! For this reason special certificates (Extended Validation SSL Certificates) were introduced, issued under even more stringent identity verification by specialized certification bodies. Some internet browsers (unfortunately not the Android browser) offer the possibility of websites with such special certificates, to recognize at first glance. Recognizable here on the green area (lock + separately displayed company name)

More information can be found at bsi-fuer-buerger.de (www.bsi-fuer-buerger.de). Here you will generally find some more information on how to safely navigate the web.\n\nGood luck revealing phishing websites. Do not let yourself be tricked!

Clicking on links can be dangerous!

In this game, you learned how to recognize by web addresses, if you are on a phishing website. We have focused on detecting the attack when you are on the website, as links can be fake as well.

Nevertheless, you should not, unreasonably, click on links if you do not trust a message from the beginning. It is possible to download malware by clicking on malicious links. Therefore, you should check the web address before clicking. It is important to know what information you can rely on; i.d.R. in the web context on the display bottom left in the browser. Critical are web addresses that you scan with a QR code scanner. Some scanners open the web page directly without displaying the web address. We therefore recommend the Privacy-Friendly QR Code Scanner, developed in the SECUSO Group.

More tricks

You've learned several tricks that phishers use to fool Internet users. However, there are other tricks that we have not dealt with in the game. The following are just examples:

Tiny-URL
It can happen that a phisher calls a so-called "Short Link" (Tiny-URL) used to disguise the real goal. 

For example, http://tinyurl.com/nskuf85 
	o the NoPhish website 

https://www.secuso.informatik.tu-darmstadt.de/de/secuso-home/research/results/nophish 

Short links are abbreviated forms of web addresses. To facilitate the typing of web addresses. You can only check the URL after the resolution. You can use the following service for this: 

 http://getlinkinfo.com/ 

On the safe side you are, if you do not click on the link but manually enter the web address with the known Who-Area.

Referrer
A referrer is submitted whenever a user visits a website through a link on another page. By means of a so-called Dereferrers one can now "disguise", from which website you originally come. If, for example, a link is called via GMX, a dereferencer is set before the actual destination URL. The original page is here �gmx.net� and the destination page "info.allyouneed.com".

https://deref-gmx.net/mail/client/dereferrer/?redirectUrl=http%3A%2F%2Finfo.allyouneed.com%2Fgo%2F0%2F1LNSD479-1LM9YF2U-1L9EOOAX-VRYAL9.html%3Frid%3D12YEEUIW-19J53LF

Here the web browser first calls up the gmx page and then opens upinfo.allyouneed.com forwarded. The Who-Area �deref-gmx.net� Unfortunately this does not say anything about the actual destination of the link. This method is e.g. applied to it, to hide secret data in the original URL like e.g. the existence of the referring website.

ccTLD
Furthermore, there are so-called ccTLDs (country-specific Top-Level-Domains). The Top-Level-Domain represents here the Who-Area. There are many legitimate websites that use this method, e.g. www.amazon.co.uk. After the rules learned before (�Just look at the last two areas before the third slash�) would as a Who-Area only co.uk to be viewed as, In this case, unfortunately, has no significance for the actual legitimacy of the website. The co stands here only for "commercial" thus for a commercial enterprise and uk for the United Kingdom.


These two tricks are currently not addressed by the rules of NoPhish yet. In future releases, however, we will extend the rules to include input for these tricks.

Country Code
Phishers also try to use other country codes:

https://www.amazon.ss
												instead of
https://www.amazon.de

In this training, the focus was on the name of the interlocutor. Often this is enough. To be sure, it is also necessary to check the country code. Here there are not only country codes but also those for cities (e.g. .Berlin) or organizations (.org).
It is therefore important, When registering on a page, you not only remember the name of the person you are talking about in the Who section, but also the country code.

Psychological Tricks
Phishers often use tricks to get you to click on a link. That's what happened in the past, that (time) pressure was built up, because otherwise the account will be blocked. 
A new trick is to offer you two links. e.g. that a bank transaction has been carried out. It will then be offered a link for �I have not done any transaction� and a link for �Yes, I have initiated this transaction�.

You have played through the game completely. We hope you have learned a lot and are now armed against common phishing tricks. If you want to continue practicing, especially to refresh what you have learned, you can jump over the level overview in each level.

Finally, please take the time for a post quiz:

• App once played through
• App played through twice

Best regards,
Your NoPhish Team
